There is only one way to be sure and enforce the invariant.

before removing, can we add? 
i.e., rather that remove test coverage, we should run both the old and the new in parallel (or control with a switch) then remove.

Tests integrated into blue for push.

You can't remove this until the one from openwhisk-catalog is installed since we have dependencies on it. IPG 256.
IPG 257.

The build.gradle file in openwhisk-catalog/test will import all the test dependencies in openwhisk. openwhisk-catalog is a repo depending on openwhisk. All the dependencies openwhisk has are able to import to openwhisk-catalog now. No matter you install openwhisk-catalog or run the test cases in openwhisk-catalog, please make openwhisk is installed first.

For more detailed information about importing the dependencies, please check: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog/blob/master/tests/build.gradle. 

The travis ci for openwhisk-catalog is already set up. Just adding a single test cases will be OK to go in openwhisk-catalog. For example: https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog/pull/30 There is a green mark for the tests.

For future development of actions, openwhisk-catalog will become the repo
hosting them. Vincent(houshengbo) is currently working on the catalog movement one by
one, please reach out to him for any concerns.

speaking pub/sub lingo a rule would be a named subscription to an event that got published via a topic we call trigger. action would be the consumer. there is some benefit to keeping a handle to the subscription. i.e. you can disable it temporarily without having to remove and add it again. afaik the topic does not know who has subscribed to it per se. it just publishes stuff (read: fires).

@domdom82 "rule would be a named subscription" is at odds with @mbehrendt comment which suggests we should admit anonymous rules. The lack of specificity and without being very concrete and careful about terminology, this discussion will meander and lack focus. 

The intent of this issues and the question posed by @markusthoemmes is borne out of the experience reimplementing the activator. It is more specific to the implementation of rules rather than an existential question of whether the whisk programming model should include rules. He should of course correct me if I'm wrong.

I think this issue has degenerated into multiple independent threads being crossed:

   1) How do we implement rule entities in the backend.
   2) Do we need a Rules API? 
   3) Do we want to support anonymous entities as an option?  
   4) Do we want Rules to be anonymous always, with no possibility to name them?

I'd suggest we narrow the scope of this issue to topic 1) Implementation concerns.

If anyone wants to argue for API changes as per 2), 3), 4) -- let's break those out as separate discussion items.
Close, given 824?
Included in #824

@csantanapr - the openwhisk build `gradle distDocker` is now producing the Go CLI binaries under the `/bin` folder.  The conmplete set of platform/cpu-architecture specific binaries are in sub folders under `/bin/go-cli/` organized by platform/arch.  Also, a softlink to the current platform (running the build) specific binary is created at `/bin/go-cli/wsk`.  You confirmed this a few days ago, so I'm closing out this issue.  Feel free to reopen if there's something else missing.
Go CLI is now fully using the docker cache.  Closing this issue.

[91mnpm^[[0m^[[91m ^[[0m^[[91mERR!^[[0m^[[91m ^[[0m^[[91mfetch failed^[[0m^[[91m https://registry.npmjs.org/abab/-/abab-1.0.3.tgz

This issue is gone.

@mdeuser, looks like the Python CLI generates an interactive prompt when "property set --namespace" is called.

As a smoke tests for this I placed the CLI in my home folder /.local/bin/go-cli, set use.cli.download to true in whisk.properties, and the tests are passing locally using that CLI. The mentioned path is where the Go CLI with be placed after it has been downloaded.
Please review.

@rabbah @markusthoemmes @csantanapr 
In order to have a seamless transition from openwhisk to openwhisk-catalog, I think we can create a script named installExtraCatalog.sh under openwhisk/catalog to install the scripts, which have already moved to openwhisk-catalog. At the same time we still keep the installCatalog.sh to install the packages, which are still in openwhisk.

In the ansible file postdeploy.yml, we can add installExtraCatalog.sh, so that after running installCatalog.sh, we can run installExtraCatalog.sh. In this case, we can make sure that no package is missed during the transition from openwhisk/catalog to openwhisk-catalog. It is possible that some packages are installed twice(e.g. openwhisk-catalog has merged that package with tests, but openwhisk has not deleted it yet), but I think it is better than some packages missing in this transition.

How to break the circular dependency? 
The good approach can be we create a new separate repo to host the install scripts. Go to <openwhisk_home> to install openwhisk and then go to <openwhisk_catalog_home> to install the catalogs based on openwhisk. **However**, since our install scripts still exist in openwhisk, we can use an additional parameter for openwhisk.yml, e.g. withExtraCatalog and withoutExtraCatalog, to determine whether to clone the openwhisk-catalog repo or not.

By default, openwhisk.yml will install the extraCatalog from openwhisk-catalog(we can change to withoutExtraCatalog for the default value if possible):

```
ansible-playbook -i environments/local openwhisk.yml 
ansible-playbook -i environments/local openwhisk.yml -e mode=withExtraCatalog or something similar
```

The above commands behave the same.

While we are able to choose the installation withoutExtraCatalog to skip the catalog installation from openwhisk-catalog by:

```
ansible-playbook -i environments/local openwhisk.yml -e mode=withoutExtraCatalog or something similar
```

**If the user starts the installation from openwhisk:** in openwhisk.yml or even postdeploy.yml, check if it is withExtraCatalog. 
If so, download the openwhisk-catalog repo and put it in the same dir as openwhisk is located, run the install scripts under openwhisk-catalog. 
If not, skip the catalog installation from openwhisk-catalog.

**If the user starts the installation from openwhisk-catalog:** in the installation script of openwhisk-catalog, check if <openwhisk_home> exists. 
If so, use this variable and install the catalog packages;
If not, download the openwhisk repo and put it in the same dir as openwhisk-catalog, install the openwhisk with the mode of withoutExtraCatalog, so that openwhisk would not check openwhisk-catalog this time. Then install the catalog packages in openwhisk-catalog.

@houshengbo you have a merge commit in this PR. We're following a policy of linear history in this repository. You can refer to https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/wiki/Contributing:-Git-guidelines for instructions on how to avoid merge commits. You can probably just remove the current merge-commit and rebase on master afterwards to fix this. Let me know if you need help doing that.

seems like in docker 1.9.1 the `--security-opt` option does not work if you put 

```
--security-opt apparmor=docker-default
```

you actually **have** to use the colon notation to make it work:

```
--security-opt apparmor:docker-default
```

Also since docker 1.11 the colon notation is deprecated (https://github.com/docker/docker/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#1110-2016-04-13)
So this will need another follow-up change once we upgrade to docker >= 1.11

--security-opts is longer supported at all.
rebased and squashed. removing wip tag.
PG 279

You can't omit the `whisk.system` prefix. This is part of the fully qualified name of the package. Maybe I don't follow the issue. `wsk action list` lists actions in the namespace that the CLI is configured for. `wsk action list /whisk.system` lists actions in `whisk.system` namespace. They are semantically different. Are you saying the go cli does not support the latter yet?
@perryibm pls review and merge / assign to committer if needed.
Works fine for me. My namespace is set to _ in the CLI properties.

The proposed Go error message when a nonexistent file name is provided is `errMsg := fmt.Sprintf("File '%s' is not a valid file or it does not exist: %s", artifact, err)`.  The `os.Stat()` is pretty much an existence test.  The existing `action create` test case is looking for 'not a valid file' in the "missing file" error message, so the Go CLI included that bit of text in that error message.  Here's the test case snippet.

```
    it should "reject create with missing file" in {
        wsk.action.create("missingFile", Some("notfound"),
            expectedExitCode = MISUSE_EXIT).
            stderr should include("not a valid file")
```
